post.record.embed.external.description: For all its strength and swagger, China is struggling to handle an impulsive America
post.record.embed.external.title: Xi Jinping’s Trump-sized puzzle
post.record.text:
China has toughness and discipline on its side in its showdown with America. But the rigidity of China’s one-party system, and its horror of exposing Xi Jinping to embarrassment, makes dealing with Trumpian chaos a nightmare. My column, “The Telegram”
economist.com/internationa...
from The Economist

post.record.text:
Donald Trump has replaced the old certainties that underpinned the world economy with extraordinary levels of volatility and confusion.

Some of the chaos may have abated for now. But it will take a very long time to rebuild what has been lost econ.st/4i6Z4Vx

The rare good-ish news story on the British economy—why Britain is surprisingly well-insulated from a tariff crash, at least compared to most of its peers:

Part, but not all of the answer is in quite how much (un-tariffed) services dominate British exports.

Link: www.economist.com/britain/202...

DOGE’s cuts have put vital gov't data at risk. Amid the chaos of Trump’s second term, it’s easy to miss—but the federal surveys we use to understand everything from the economy to maternal mortality to healthcare costs are under threat. My piece this week: www.economist.com/united-state...

China has a big beautiful opportunity. Xi Jinping’s paranoid nationalism used to seem like dystopian hyperbole. Now that Donald Trump is committing such wanton self-harm and general destruction, it looks ahead of its time econ.st/3E4l0mp

But there are wrinkles galore, explored in my latest @economist.com, with insights from @nbagley.bsky.social and Alan Morrison. www.economist.com/united-state...

But buying more time for phase-two talks does not mean those talks will succeed: they will run up against a familiar problem, that both sides have incompatible demands. www.economist.com/middle-east-...
post.embed.external.title: Israel and Hamas have something in common
post.embed.external.description: They both want to avoid a ceasefire collapse, for a few more weeks

post.record.embed.external.description: His death at the age of 70 comes during the sort of upheaval that he was exceptionally good at interpreting
post.record.embed.external.title: John Parker, one of The Economist’s finest correspondents, was a polymath journalist
post.record.text:
Some sad news to share: John Parker, one of The Economist’s finest correspondents, has died at the age of 70.

At a time of global upheaval the world has lost one of the people best able to interpret momentous change. We remember his lengthy career econ.st/4kjEOm4
post.embed.external.title: John Parker, one of The Economist’s finest correspondents, was a polymath journalist
post.embed.external.description: His death at the age of 70 comes during the sort of upheaval that he was exceptionally good at interpreting

post.record.embed.external.description: Macron, Tusk, Costa: the runners and riders for the job from hell
post.record.embed.external.title: Which European should face off against Trump and Putin?
post.record.text:
Europe is desperately–and justifiably–keen to be a party to Ukraine peace talks.

In practice it will be allowed ONE envoy to face off against Trump and Putin.

Who should it be?
Charlemagne this week considers the main candidates. Should it be Costa? Macron? Tusk?

www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

post.record.embed.external.description: A proposed economic deal would be punitive. Saying “no” could be worse
post.record.embed.external.title: Donald Trump makes Ukraine an offer it can’t refuse
post.record.text: Here’s our piece on the state of play in the Ukraine-US mineral “deal”. Tldr: the American proposal is unclear, punitive and makes no sense. There are perfectly good ways for Ukraine to reward America for support by letting it exploit mineral deposits. This is not one of them.
post.embed.external.title: Donald Trump makes Ukraine an offer it can’t refuse
post.embed.external.description: A proposed economic deal would be punitive. Saying “no” could be worse

post.record.text:
The Americans called it a “transaction of love.” The Ukrainian officials I spoke to called it differently: “not negotiation, but extortion”.

www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

post.record.embed.external.title: Donald Trump makes Ukraine an offer it can’t refuse
post.record.text: Ukrainian officials say their encounters with Donald Trump’s team are so confusing that they have been watching documentaries for clues about his negotiation style. There have been three versions of a deal, considered “bad”, “better” and “disastrous” econ.st/3XhvSno

post.record.text: My piece this week on the dilemma facing countries like Egypt and Jordan. For decades, America saw them as linchpins of regional stability. post.record.text:
To reflect the momentous events of the past week we designed two covers featuring Donald Trump.

One explains how Europe must respond as he and Vladimir Putin smash the post-war order econ.st/41vGi5q

The other considers the power of the president econ.st/4gRbzUD

post.record.embed.external.description: How far would you go in the pursuit of perfection?
post.record.embed.external.title: The hormone that grew me
post.record.text:
“Once you go there, you won’t go back”

I followed the black market in human growth hormone for @economist.com's The Weekend Intelligence. I met doctors, users and drug dealers to understand our quest to optimise ourselves, and what it can ultimately cost. 

www.economist.com/podcasts/202...

post.record.text:
My year-long investigation into the multibillion dollar world of online scams is out today  — on the cover of The Economist and in my new 8-part podcast series, Scam Inc

Read the article: bit.ly/scam-inc
Listen to the podcast: econ.st/3CFzGaL
post.embed.record.value.text: Online scamming is a vast, sophisticated and fast-growing global enterprise that compares in size and scope to the illegal drug industry. Except that in many ways it is worse. As our investigation finds, nobody is safe from Scam Inc econ.st/4gvEhdm

post.record.embed.external.description: And Taiwan is struggling to deal with the growing number of spies
post.record.embed.external.title: China is infiltrating Taiwan’s armed forces
post.record.text:
Taiwan's armed forces have a Chinese spy problem. Prosecutions for Chinese espionage have jumped fourfold in the last 4 years. 2/3 of alleged spies last year were current or retired military personnel. China is also using new tactics to recruit younger collaborators
www.economist.com/asia/2025/02...
post.embed.external.title: China is infiltrating Taiwan’s armed forces
